verb.description: Bear all or part of the weight of; hold up.
examples: the dome was supported by a hundred white columns

verb.description: Give assistance to, especially financially; enable to function or act.
examples: the government gives $2.5 billion a year to support the activities of the voluntary sector

verb.description: (of a computer or operating system) allow the use or operation of (a program, language, or device)
examples: the new versions do not support the graphical user interface standard
at work during the day I could support the grief

noun.description: A thing that bears the weight of something or keeps it upright.
examples: the best support for a camera is a tripod
he urged that military support be sent to protect humanitarian convoys

phrases: air operations in support of the land forces
The earlier doctrines were written for urban operations in support of conventional forces.
Some users may require other centralized utility systems in support of their operations.
The army, however, wanted the air force to operate primarily in support of land operations.
Substantial numbers of police officers preserve the peace in support of operational police colleagues.
origin: Middle English (originally in the sense tolerate): from Old French supporter, from Latin supportare, from sub- from below + portare carry.
